text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with bigos that's right we're gonna
make what's described as a polish hunter
stew which is a pretty ironic name if
you consider which meats we're gonna use
since what kind of hunter goes out and
shoots farm animals I mean if you give
me enough ammunition in a small enough
field I think even I could bag a cow but
anyway we'll get into what meats we're
gonna use later because first up we have
to prep our cabbage base and to begin
that we'll add a couple cups of drained
sauerkraut to a Dutch oven that we've
already added a couple tablespoons of
butter and by the way I did not rinse
the sauerkraut I think having a little
bit of that brine detached is gonna add
some nice seasoning here and then to our
fermented cabbage we will also add some
fresh cabbage that we've sliced up just
like we're making coleslaw and what
we'll do is go ahead and set our heat to
medium-low and then we'll also want to
play some kind of frying pan or skillet
next to that because what we're going to
do while our cabbage comes up to
temperature
besides give it a stir every once in a
while is brown up and add all our
various meats and the first one we're
gonna start with will be some sliced up
bacon since once all that fat renders
out of it we will have all that goodness
available to brown up the rest of our
meats so we'll toss in some bacon and
cook that over medium-high heat while
our cabbage mixture slowly sweats next
to it on medium-low heat and then the
game plan here is whenever one of our
meats finishes browning
we'll simply add it to the pot of
cabbage and continue on so we'll go
ahead and brown up that bacon until it's
well cooked but not quite crisp at which
point like I said we'll transfer that in
and then in that exact same pan we did
our bacon we will move on to brown up
our pork shoulder which has been cut
into about one-and-a-half inch pieces
and we will also season that up a little
bit of salt and by the way to make a
real Polish under stew you're gonna want
to go out stock and kill a wild boar but
if unsuccessful this pork shoulder will
work beautifully so we'll go ahead and
brown up that pork in our bacon fat and
then go ahead and transfer that into our
Dutch oven and then once that set we
will move on to our third type of meat
which ideally would be venison but like
most people that make this these days
I'm gonna use beef beef chuck to be
exact and we'll want to season that with
salt as well in case you're curious beef
chuck
comes from the shoulder which means it
has a good amount of fat and works
perfectly in dishes like this in other
stews but anyway we'll go ahead and
brown that up just like the pork and I
should mention at any time during this
process if you feel like there's getting
to be too much fat in the pan and it's
kind of splattering all over and you're
afraid of a grease fire
feel free to blot some out with a paper
towel or even carefully spoon some out
because in any given time you only need
like two or three tablespoons of fat in
there to do this job so something to
keep an eye on and then once our beef
has been browned we will move on to our
fourth and fifth and final meats which
for me is gonna be two different kinds
of sausage that I went ahead and sliced
up and the lighter colored one is
bratwurst and the redder colored one
should be Polish sausage but I ended up
going with andouille which is basically
the Polish sausage of Louisiana and
really quite excellent in this and then
just like the beef and the pork we'll go
ahead and brown this up and then once
that's been accomplished we are finally
done browning the meats but not using
the pan so once our sausage has been
transferred in we'll reduce the heat to
medium and add one large chopped onion
along with a pinch of salt and we'll
want to cook this on medium until it
starts to turn translucent and maybe
start to get a little bit of color on it
so we'll cook that stirring for a few
minutes over medium heat and once those
onions do soften up we will want to add
the following two ingredients some dried
mushrooms that we're gonna soak in water
till they're soft enough to chop up and
today I'll be using my favorite dried
mushroom the porcini although any dried
mushroom will work and then besides
soaking and chopping those I'm also
gonna dice up three dried plums or as
our parents would have called them
prunes so same thing just a more
marketable name and then like I said
once our onions have cooked long enough
and sort of look like this we'll go
ahead and stir those in and as far as
balancing flavors the sweetness from
that dried fruit is kind of important
although I have seen recipes that use
honey instead so that's another option
but anyway what we'll do is stir those
in and let them cook with the onions for
about two minutes before adding and
reducing one cup of dry red wine and
when I say dry I simply mean any wine
that's not a dessert wine
okay don't add pork to this so really
any kind of red
Mayans gonna work here and what we'll do
is add that and raise our heat to
medium-high and we'll cook that stirring
it once in a while until it's pretty
much almost gone and as usual with all
productions be careful do not let it
burn otherwise you're starting over so
we'll keep an eye on that and cook it
until it sort of looks like this and
there's only a little bit left at which
point we can go ahead and add this to
our sausage and cabbage mixture and move
on to final production and all that
means is we're going to add in our
secret herbs and spices which will
include some paprika some caraway seeds
some dry thyme a little bit of allspice
as well as we'll also toss in one bay
leaf and then last but not least some
freshly ground black pepper and then
once everything's in we'll go ahead and
take a spoon and give this a thorough
mixing and then if you want some people
like to add some broth or water at this
point but I don't I want all the
moisture in this just to come from our
onions and cabbage okay so there are wet
brothy versions of this but I believe
the drier versions the one I'm making
here our superior in taste and texture
so I'm not going to add any additional
liquid all I'm going to do after giving
it a stir is cover it tightly and let it
simmer on low to medium low until our
meat is tender and of course every once
in a while we will uncover it and give
it a stir and exactly how long you're
gonna cook this depends on how big your
pieces of meat were right this might
take an hour this might take an hour and
a half hey it could even take two hours
who knows so I covered it back up and
continue to let it simmer and I believe
mine simmered for a total of about an
hour and a half but do not go by time
which is why we always test so I gave it
a stir and grabbed a fork and stabbed a
piece of beef and it was tender which
means I'm probably done but to make sure
I also tasted a piece of pork and in
addition to testing for doneness you're
also testing for seasoning and I'm happy
to report my was perfect and did not
need anything and then what we'll do
once we determined our meat is tender is
go ahead and turn off the heat and
proceed to make a very major decision
are we going to serve it immediately
which we certainly can or as tradition
will we let this cool down and then
refrigerate it overnight before
reheating the next day and then serving
so that is totally gonna be up to you
you are after all me amigos of your
bigos but since you are my good friends
I will recommend not serving this till
the next day it really is better all
those flavors really develop and deepen
so that's what I did I let it cool put
it in the fridge and then brought it out
the next day and to be safe when we go
to reheat it I do like to add a splash
of water not a lot maybe a quarter cup
and then what we'll do is heat that up
gently on somewhere between low and
medium low and as that comes up to
temperature make sure you give it a stir
once a while and you also want to check
the moisture level okay because if it's
too dry and your heats too high there is
a chance it could start to stick and
burn but if you keep your heat on low to
medium low you should not have a problem
and then once we've determined that's
hot and delicious we'll go ahead and
serve up a nice large portion and please
be generous all right it's called bigos
not little oohs which reminds me all you
health nuts and paleo Tron's we'll be
happy to know this is very low carb
which is why after garnishing with a
little bit of fresh thyme I'm gonna
serve this with some buttered bread and
wine and that my friends is one of the
greatest cold-weather dishes of all time
and how other dishes of all time okay
all that meat and cabbage has formed an
amazing amalgamation that is beyond
savory all right this stuff is an umami
bomb in every sense of the word with
everybody exploding with flavor plus I
think we have that perfect interplay
between our tangy elements and those
sweet elements so really just a
profoundly delicious bite of food and
with the help of this bread when I
finish it's gonna look like the dish was
already washed that is exactly the kind
of recipe this is and since I am 25%
polish I'll assume this is at least 1/4
authentic and even though we didn't use
any wild game we shot ourselves I still
think we achieved a very rustic hearty
and comforting dish and with a cold
chilly weather upon us one I really do
hope you try to make soon so head over
to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts of more info as usual
and dissolve
enjoy
[Music]
